title: 112_hr1931
content: The Act may be cited as the "Groundwork USA Trust Act of 2011". Congress recognizes the importance of locally organized entities in leading cost-effective projects that improve the environment, economy, and quality of life. Community involvement in land use is crucial for economic success. Neglected vacant lands decrease property values and burden tax bases. Involving citizens in landscaping and maintenance reduces negative stigma, promotes civic pride, and deters vandalism and illicit activities. Transforming idle lands and brownfields through cleaning, landscaping, and tree planting adds economic value to communities by increasing occupancy rates and enhancing the appeal of nearby real estate. This initiative, exemplified by federally backed Groundwork USA Trusts for over 8 years, helps combat vandalism and illicit activities typically associated with neglected vacant lands. The text chunk discusses the definitions outlined in Section 3. In Section 3 of the Act, definitions are provided for terms such as brownfields, eligible organization, Groundwork USA national office, and Groundwork USA Trust. Groundwork USA Trust is an independent nonprofit environmental organization that works with communities to improve their environment, economy, and quality of life through local action. Nonprofit organization refers to an organization exempt from tax under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code. Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. Establishment of Groundwork USA Trust Program authorizes the Secretary to award grants to eligible organizations in consultation with the Groundwork USA national office. Eligible organizations must submit an application containing required information. Criteria for selection are outlined. Each grant award under section 4(a) is based on the quality of the application, considering factors such as population demographics, experience with community and environmental activities, past funding from EPA Brownfields Program, and organizational capabilities. The eligibility criteria for grant awards include the organization's partnership with the National Park Service, community interest in partnering with Groundwork USA Trust, and opportunities for environmental improvement and economic development. The potential benefits of addressing brownfield issues include economic and environmental rejuvenation of communities, increasing capacity for improvement, engaging the local community in planning and development, and contributing to the use of existing infrastructure. The potential benefits of addressing brownfield issues include leveraging funds, engaging the local community, reducing health and environmental threats, and facilitating reuse for community benefits. The potential benefits of addressing brownfield issues include helping to identify and reduce threats to the health and welfare of at-risk populations. SEC. 6. USE OF FUNDS. The grant award provided under the program can be used for training, research, and technical assistance to facilitate brownfield site inventory, assessments, and remediation, as well as community involvement and site preparation. It aims to increase community capacity for environmental care, reclaim vacant lands for conservation and economic development, clean up neglected areas for community pride, restore blighted landscapes, and integrate various aspects like environmental education and job training. The program aims to support various initiatives such as health and fitness, resource management, job training, sustainable environmental care, urban environmental improvements, property rehabilitation, and expanding operations to benefit a larger geographic area. The program aims to support initiatives such as health and fitness, resource management, job training, sustainable environmental care, urban improvements, property rehabilitation, and expanding operations to benefit a larger area. Additionally, it includes developing information systems for research and data dissemination, and fostering partnerships with other environmental organizations. The maximum grant award for the program is $400,000 per fiscal year. The Secretary can allocate up to 15% of the funds for administrative costs. Grant recipients must submit annual reports to the Secretary and the national Groundwork USA office. $15,000,000 is authorized for the program annually from 2012 to 2017.
